content: {{knowledge objective |Identifiant=OIC-094-16-B |Item_parent=Rachialgia |Item_parent_short=Rachialgia |Rank=B |Title=Knowing the diagnostic approach to coccygodynia |Description=None |Rubric=Positive diagnosis |Contributors=Bisseriex Hélène,Nguyen Christelle |Order=16}} '''Positive diagnosis:''' - pain localised to the coccygeal area, without significant radiation - reproduced by palpation/mobilisation of the coccyx or sacro-coccygeal region - exacerbated by sitting and/or rising from a seated position - functional discomfort: sitting (in the car, at work, etc.) '''Etiological referral:''' pain in the seat > suspected subluxation and/or fracture '''Recherche facteur déclenchant :''' - trauma: very short delay between trauma and pain = certain liability; delay < 1 month = very likely liability; delay > 3 months, unlikely liability - obesity/pregnancy = risk factor for subluxation '''Differential diagnosis''': sacroiliac pain, anal '''[[Anal pain SDD-005|(anal pain)]]''', lumbar with coccygeal irradiation, pudendal neuralgia '''[[Pelvic pain SDD-099|(pelvic pain,]]''' '''[[Testicular pain SDD-100|testicular pain)]]'''' '''Duration of evolution:''' acute or chronic (most acute coccygodynia heals spontaneously within a few weeks)

question.title: What is the primary diagnostic approach to coccygodynia?
question.description: A question about the diagnostic approach to coccygodynia

option_a.title: Imaging studies
option_a.description: Imaging studies are often used to diagnose coccygodynia

option_b.title: Physical examination and medical history
option_b.description: A thorough physical examination and medical history are crucial in diagnosing coccygodynia

option_c.title: Blood tests and laboratory studies
option_c.description: Blood tests and laboratory studies are often used to rule out other conditions

option_d.title: Electromyography and nerve conduction studies
option_d.description: Electromyography and nerve conduction studies are used to diagnose nerve damage

correct_option.title: Physical examination and medical history
